metadata./Title: Mass-forming type 2 autoimmune pancreatitis with upstream dilatation of the main pancreatic duct dilatation: a case report

sections.Background:
Background Type 2 autoimmune pancreatitis is characterized by multiple or segmental strictures of the main 
pancreatic duct without upstream dilatation. We encountered a case of mass-forming type 2 autoimmune pancreatitis with upstream main pancreatic duct dilatation that was difficult to diagnose preoperatively using endoscopic 
ultrasound sonography-guided fine-needle aspiration cytology.
sections.Case Presentation:
Case presentation A 58-year-old Japanese man presented with recurrent acute pancreatitis secondary to a 10-mm 
pancreatic head tumor. The tumor compressed the main pancreatic duct, thereby dilating the upstream main pancre atic duct. The serum immunoglobin G4 levels were within normal limits. Endoscopic ultrasound sonography-guided 
fine-needle aspiration cytology was performed twice. However, few degenerative atypical cells were observed, 
resulting in an indeterminate diagnosis. The patient underwent pancreaticoduodenectomy, and pathological findings 
revealed duct-centric pancreatitis with neutrophilic infiltration of the interlobular pancreatic ductal epithelium. Immunoglobin G4-positive cells were not detected. The patient was diagnosed with type 2 autoimmune pancreatitis.
sections.Conclusion:
Conclusion Mass-forming type 2 autoimmune pancreatitis can present with main pancreatic duct strictures 
and upstream dilatation. Although endoscopic ultrasound sonography-guided fine-needle aspiration cytology is use ful for the diagnosis of solid pancreatic masses, preoperative diagnosis of type 2 autoimmune pancreatitis remains 
challenging. Further studies should be conducted to determine whether “hidden” type 2 autoimmune pancreatitis 
may be more frequently present and to improve the accuracy of the diagnosis of type 2 autoimmune pancreatitis.
Keywords  Type 2 autoimmune pancreatitis, Endoscopic ultrasound sonography, Pancreatic cancer, 
Pancreaticoduodenectomy, Case report
Background
Autoimmune pancreatitis (AIP) is a unique type of 
chronic pancreatitis characterized by morphological, 
histological, and serological features [1]. The well known form is type 1 AIP , which is a manifestation of immu noglobin G4 (IgG4)-related disease [2]. Type 1 AIP is 
characterized by positive serum IgG4, image findings 
including capsule-like low-density rim appearance, mul tiple strictures of main pancreatic duct (MPD) [3], and 
lobule-centric inflammation pattern in pathological find ings. In contrast, type 2 AIP is a minor form of AIP in 
Japan, featuring granulocytic epithelial lesions (GEL), a 
high rate of coexisting inflammatory bowel diseases, and 
the absence of serum IgG4 [4].*Correspondence:

The differential diagnosis of small-sized mass-forming 
AIP from pancreatic cancer is challenging [5]. A typi cal case of AIP shows narrowing of over one third of 
the MPD without significant dilatation of the upstream 
MPD [6]. The absence of characteristic findings, such as 
elevated serum IgG4 levels in type 2 AIP , makes accurate 
diagnosis increasingly difficult.
Here, we report a case of mass-forming type 2 AIP with 
dilatation of the upstream MPD that was difficult to diag nose preoperatively.
Case presentation
A 58-year-old Japanese man with no history of inflam matory bowel diseases was referred to our hospital for 
further evaluation and treatment of recurrent pancreati tis. The patient initially presented with vomiting and epi gastric pain. His primary care doctor noted high blood 
amylase levels (1022  U/L) on blood chemistry tests. No 
evidence of elevated alkaline phosphatase or bilirubin 
level was detected. Computed tomography (CT) showed 
a 9-mm large low-density area in the pancreatic head 
(Fig.  1a) and swelling of the pancreas from the body to 
the tail with a dilated main pancreatic duct (Fig.  1b); 
ascites was not detected at this time. He was diagnosed 
with acute pancreatitis, followed by the administration 
of gabexate mesylate for 10 days. Although his symptoms 
improved after treatment, a restart of oral intake wors ened the abdominal pain and the elevation of the blood 
amylase level relapsed. Carcinoembryonic antigen and 
carbohydrate antigen 19–9 were elevated to 5.3  ng/ml 
and 116.5  U/ml. The duke pancreatic monoclonal anti gen type (DUPAN)−2 levels were within normal lim its. Serum IgG4 level was also negative. The patient was 
transferred to our hospital and underwent endoscopic retrograde pancreatography (ERP) with pancreatic duct 
plastic stent placement (Fig.  2a). The main pancreatic 
duct adjacent to the tumor was stenosed segmentally at 
the pancreatic head (Fig .2b). Other stenoses of the main 
pancreatic duct were not detected; however, upstream 
dilatation (>  5  mm) was observed. Pancreatic juice and 
pancreatic duct brush cytology revealed no malignan cies. A reassessed CT scan revealed a remaining lowdensity area without enhancement of the pancreatic head 
next to the main pancreatic duct. The main pancreatic 
duct was stenotic in this position, with upstream dilata tion. Contrast-enhanced magnetic resonance imaging 
(MRI) revealed a space-occupying lesion in the pancre atic head adjacent to the main pancreatic duct during the 
portal phase (Fig.  3a). MPD dilatation was observed on 
magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography (Fig.  3b). 
Fluorodeoxyglucose (FDG)-positron emission tomog raphy (PET) showed slight uptake with a maximum 
standardized uptake value of 3.8 at the pancreatic head 
lesion, whereas no extrapancreatic lesions were detected 
(Fig.  4). Endoscopic ultrasound sonography (EUS) was 
performed, and a 10-mm tumor in size was noted in the 
pancreatic head (Fig.  5). EUS-guided fine-needle aspi ration (EUS-FNA) was performed twice; however, few 
degenerative atypical cells were observed, resulting in an 
indeterminate diagnosis [7]. We thoroughly discussed 
the possibility of cancer and surgical indications, and the 
patient decided to undergo a pancreaticoduodenectomy 
with D2 lymph node dissection.
During surgery, there were inflammatory adhesions 
around the pancreas due to repeated pancreatitis. The 
tumor in the pancreatic head was not palpable. In pan creaticojejunostomy, we performed interrupted suturing 
of the pancreatic parenchyma and jejunal seromuscular

Based on these findings, the patient was diagnosed with 
type 2 AIP . The postoperative course was uneventful. 
Although steroids and immunosuppressive drugs were 
not used postoperatively, type 2 AIP did not relapse. The

sections.Discussion:
Discussion
Here, we report a case of mass-forming type 2 AIP 
with upstream dilatation of the main pancreatic duct. 
Although EUS-FNA was performed twice, a definitive 
preoperative diagnosis was not made.
Mass-forming type 2 AIP can present with upstream 
dilatation of the MPD. Type 2 AIP is a minor form of AIP . 
An international multicenter study reported 1064 cases 
of AIP , and the proportion of type 2 AIP was 14% in the 
USA, 13% in Europe, and 4% in Asia, including Japan [8]. 
The international consensus diagnostic criteria for AIP 
include ductal imaging of ERP showing long (> 1/3 of the 
length of the MPD) or multiple strictures without marked 
upstream dilatation [9, 10]. In contrast, in the present 
case, a tumor in the pancreatic head caused MPD ste nosis, leading to upstream dilatation of MPD (> 5 mm). 
This finding was suggestive of pancreatic cancer, mak ing the differential diagnosis more difficult. Addition ally, repeated pancreatitis caused by MPD stenosis, slight 
uptake of the tumor on FDG-PET, and elevation of tumor 
markers indicated pancreatic cancer.Mass-forming type 2 AIP is difficult to diagnose preop eratively even if EUS-FNA is performed. With the rapid 
development of techniques and devices for EUS-FNA and 
fine-needle biopsy (FNB), diagnostic accuracy for solid 
pancreatic masses has improved [11]. Preoperative EUS 
and EUS-FNA are beneficial for the definitive diagnosis 
of pancreatic cancer [12] and these approaches are useful 
for the differential diagnosis of type 1 and type 2 AIP [13, 
14]. A recent study reported that the diagnostic accuracy 
of EUS-FNB was 98.7%; however, pathological diagnosis 
was confirmed in 64.3% of small lesions (< 10 mm) [15]. 
A nationwide survey of AIP in Japan reported that more 
than 60% of AIP cases could not be histologically diag nosed using EUS-FNA alone [16]. Although the detec tion of abundant IgG4-positive cells helps diagnose type 
1 AIP , evaluating GEL or duct-centric pattern inflamma tion to diagnose type 2 AIP may be difficult because of 
the small sample volume in EUS-FNA.
FDG-PET may be a helpful approach for distinguish ing AIP from pancreatic cancer. Although both AIP and 
pancreatic cancer may show FDG uptake, the difference 
in uptake levels may help distinguish between these two 
diseases [17]. As pancreatic cancer may show stronger 
uptake than AIP , tumors with slight uptake should be 
evaluated carefully considering the possibility of benign 
lesions.
The next challenge in preoperatively diagnosing type 
2 AIP is deciding how to perform diagnostic treatment. 
The treatment strategy for autoimmune pancreatitis, 
including both types 1 and 2, involves administration of 
corticosteroids [8]. If the tumor has a high probability of 
autoimmune pancreatitis with no evidence of malignancy 
on histopathological examination, steroid administration 
may be considered as diagnostic therapy [18]. However, 
if a patient has cancer, there is a risk of delay in initiating 
treatment and possible cancer progression. In addition, 
some cases of pancreatic cancer with type 1 AIP have 
been reported [19]. In the present case, administration of 
corticosteroids as diagnostic therapy followed by evalu ation of the response to corticosteroid treatment could 
be a feasible treatment strategy, although the patient 
decided to undergo surgery with thorough discussion.
Conclusion
Mass-forming type 2 AIP can present with MPD stric tures and upstream MPD dilatation. Although EUS-FNA 
is useful for the diagnosis of solid pancreatic masses, 
preoperative diagnosis of type 2 AIP remains challeng ing. We must be aware that type 2 AIP can manifest 
mass-forming type and upstream dilatation of MPD,
